22509784.review:
Danganronpa 2: Goodbye Despair, developed by Spike Chunsoft and published by Spike Chunsoft Co., Ltd. themselves. Danganronpa 2: Goodbye Despair sequel to Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc is not your typical visual novel where you will find romance and everything goes smoothly. Characters will die whether you hate them or love them. It has the touch of mystery, horror, point and click and detective work all in the mix of this visual novel not to mention the story is very interesting with and filled with unexpected twists around.

[h1]The Story[/h1]
The story is definitely one of the most interesting mystery and crazy story I have read. It has many plot twists and it is very confusing in a sense that it manages to conceal the truth until the very end of every case. I always end up suspecting the wrong character as the murderer, which surprises me and the cases are very detailed . [Especially for the final case]

The story takes place after the events of Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc. You will be placed into the shoes of Hajime Hinata. Who appears to be in front of Hope’s Peak Academy a government funded school for the privileged elite of society. A door then suddenly appears in front Hajime Hinata which leads to a classrooms where he meets his classmates that has also ended up in the same situation as him of not knowing how they ended up in the class room. After some verbal exchanges in between them, their teacher named Usami revealed to them that they are on a school trip on Jabberwock Island a paradise-like island. Usami then tells them they are on a school trip and they are to befriend each other to gain hope fragments and make their hope grow. What could go wrong here? Right?:) Of course not!! What are you thinking? Upupupupu Monokuma suddenly appears and takes control of the island, announcing that the students must participate in his murderous game if they wish to escape. Leaving them in despair, being placed in a game where they are being pressured subconsciously to kill their friend or not to kill in order to escape. But if they do not kill they may become the next target with all these pressure building up around them it is bound that someone will give in to it and it starts to turn ugly for them.

[b]Characters are very memorable,[/b] each of them are unique and have some special traits about them. Personally my favorite character in Danganronpa 2: Goodbye Despair is Nanami Chiaki 七海 千秋 The Ultimate Gamer, she has that warm and cute side to her and is always there for Hajime Hinata [You in this case]. She is also highly knowledgeable about all genres of video games. She has a tendency to collect her thoughts before she starts speaking, so when she meets someone for the first time, the conversation is rather slow.
Though she’s very passionate about video games, if Nanami Chiaki gets too comfortable she falls asleep, when she is standing up or midway through a conversation or even in a tense situation where killings are occurring.

[h1]Audio and Visual Elements[/h1]
[b]Visual Elements [/b]– Many things to note here is that the backgrounds, CGs and character sprites used in Danganronpa 2: Goodbye Despair are very consistent with each other in turn made the whole visual novel as whole looks smoother. This is really a huge thing for me overall I absolutely adore the artstyle used in Danganronpa 2: Goodbye Despair. I have played many visual novels where the character sprites are not consistent with the backgrounds at all and then in turn they do not blend in nicely causing them to not look nice or“smooth” at all. The sprites used are pretty much being used all the time in game except for the CGs.

[b]Audio Elements [/b]- Music is a very important factor to consider in a visual novel because music has a great ability to set the mood and make things flow from then on. Though Danganronpa 2: Goodbye Despair reused many of the first game’s music but added a few new additions. Danganronpa 2: Goodbye Despair definitely has this executed perfectly. Each time the “phase” of the story chances, the BGM would change with it to set the mood and tension around the characters. Lets take for example in “logic dive” it uses this song called “Drive Drive”it is a new game mode that has been added into, I absolutely love the BGM as it is so fast paced and fits in with all the action that is going on.

[h1]To sum up[/h1]
Will I recommend this? Simple answer is yes. I would definitely recommend this awesome visual novel if you are the type of person who looks for gameplay in a visual novel as this definitely has loads of gameplay to offer and for people who loves detective work with dark mysteries waiting to be uncovered and solved go for it. Honestly I am not a fan of having gameplay in my visual novel I am more of the type of person that prefers to just click on my mouse all day long, but Danganronpa 2: Goodbye Despair has so much to offer, as it manages to rope me into with its rich story and great music with good gameplay. Though there are some things to point out on “hangman’s gambit” in Danganronpa 2: Goodbye Despair compared to  Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc hangman gambit in Danganronpa 2 has quite a difficulty spike as it requires more attention to get the letters right and has a higher chance of failing. [I failed 2 – 3 times for the final case]

I have been provided a review copy for Danganronpa 2: Goodbye Despair but it has no impact on this review in any way.

[spoiler]P.S Enoshima Junko is best girl well.. I like Nanami but kind of prefer Enoshima Junko[/spoiler]

To preface this, my first [i]experience[/i] with SDR2 was over two years ago, through a Let's Play on Youtube, with a shite college dorm internet connection that only allowed 240p streaming, and of course the game was unsubbed at that point so I had to rely on a MS Paint-edited translation (which I am infinitely grateful for) without fluent English support.

But I digress, because
[b]IT. WAS. AMAZING.[/b]

It was the kind of mindfuck that leaves you obsessively thinking about it until you meet them years later and you really regret that one night stand at the back of the bar™ because now they look perfectly stunning and you wish you could erase that dirty first encounter and experience it properly, with all the love and attention they rightfully deserve. 

I made a mistake. 

But [b]YOU[/b]. [i]You've[/i] been given a chance. A fresh start with an untainted mind. Welcome ultimate despair into your heart. Experience this terrible excuse for a game (because it should really be a religion) the way it was meant to be played. On a semi-HD quality PC port with not-entirely-cringeworthy dub VAs. [b]DO THE RIGHT THING[/b]

Ahah...good news though, DRV3 is coming out soon. So if anyone needs me I'll be locked up in a basement without internet connection until [i]that[/i] gets ported. Now offering support groups for alpha wave SDR2 survivors.

22509540.review:
Sixteen highschool students, trapped in a tropical paradise, are forced to kill each other. The only way to make it off the island is to murder a fellow classmate and not get caught by the remaining students. If they manage to deduce the killer, the murderer is executed. If they fail to deduce the killer, they are executed. This is Danganronpa 2.

First of all I recommend you play Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc if you haven't. While this sequel doesn't require you to have played the first game to understand the story, certain characters, events, and the backdrop for the story are more thoroughly explained in Danganronpa 1.

Danganronpa 2 puts you in the shoes of Hajime Hinata, an extraordinary highschool student known as an "Ultimate". Ultimates are simply put, the best possible high school student in a specific field. "Ultimate" baseball player, "Ultimate" martial artist, etc. However, Hajime [strike]is the Ultimate cliché[/strike] has amnesia, and can't actually remember his Ultimate ability. Hajime and 15 other "Ultimates" are taken on a field trip to a peaceful and relaxing island with a giant bomb at the center of it planted by a stuffed bear and the only way to get off the island before it explodes is to get away with murder. Wait. What?

Danganronpa 2 can be best described as absurd yet logical. Taking itself just the right amount of seriously, it combines the two concepts into one majestic game that is just as likely to confuse you with its quirks as it is to confuse you with its complex logic problems. Once the inevitable murder of one of your classmates happens, the game splits into two parts: the murder investigation, and the class trial. During the investigation, you're left to explore the island in 2D adventure game style, finding evidence and speaking with witnesses. After an arbitrary amount of time passes that the game dictates, the class trial starts. Found in the form of you deducing the murderer behind your classmates death, the puzzles are outrageously unique. Contrary to the first Danganronpa, murders are less predictable. The events are complex, and much more detailed than in the first game, and while they are off the wall and require metaphorical backflips to deduce, the answers are always logical. 

On the other hand, the trial part of the game is more annoying than logical. Playing out like Phoenix Wright, you present your evidence that you collected after the murder happened, and present your theories. Unfortunately, much like Phoenix Wright, you don't actually get punished for guessing incorrectly. Selecting the wrong answer will cause the game to immediately point out that it's incorrect, and if you get too many incorrect, you have to start the entire trial over again. In addition, your many other classmates in the trial don't actually solve anything. Their only reason for existence is to challenge your deductions, and to make you play worthless minigames that don't actually add anything to the story, but are rather put in place to ensure that the player is truly [i]understanding[/i] the storyline. Unfortunately many of these minigames require exact input of the answer that the game wants you to input. You could have a thorough understanding of the murder and events, and yet fail due to phrasing or the exact word isn't what the game was looking for. Multiple trials take place during the game.

In addition to the murders, gameplay also involves a simple social simulator. You can become friends with the other students, giving them their preferred gifts and them giving you information about themselves in return. It's all rather shallow, but nothing that detracts from the overall story.

The storyline is fantastic. It all comes together at the end in the most magnificent way possible, and compared to the complete predictability of the first game, is entirely unpredictable until the very end. The characters are all interesting, the dialogue is genius in the most absurd way possible, the voice acting is top notch, the puzzles are superb, the mystery is complex, the soundtrack is decent, and the graphics are unique. Much like a storybook, your environments seem to be made of paper, and "pop up" into existence, and the beautiful island can be fully explored without all the bloodstains after you complete the main storyline and unlock "Island Mode", an alternate reality where the murders never take place and you spend your days levelling up your students and performing activities. Not the deepest of game modes, but it's a nice addition for those concerned with longevity.

The only true downside are the minigames. Longer and more annoying than in Danganronpa 1, but just as finicky and arbitrary, these only serve to frustrate. However, the storyline more than makes up for it. If you like complex puzzles, unpredictable yet intelligent storylines, absurd humor, or you simply want to play something unique, unlike any game you've played before, then give Danganronpa 2 a try. I wholeheartedly recommend it.

终于从PSP平台移植到了PC端，也因此得以入正表示自己的支持。在推理系游戏里，弹丸论破系列凭借卓越的世界观设定和独特有趣的学级裁判系统赢得了包括我在内的很多玩家的青睐。狛哥V587！！

总的来说，加分项：
-优秀的世界观背景
-融合了多种游戏方式的学级裁判模式
-能刷NPC好感度尤其是萌妹子们！2333 （我只是想聊天而已你们别想多了23333）
-相当充实而紧凑的剧情
-BGM好评，很多时候很能烘托气氛

减分项：
-剧情模式里有些NPC好感度也太难刷了吧？事先没有被剧透过的朋友很有可能会被坑然后刷不到想要的技能orz
  （想刷技能推荐一周目通关后的爱岛模式，不过很多人游戏通完一遍看完剧情也就结束了）
-开头一长段剧情，既不能存档也不能正常的退出游戏orz

总之这是我喜欢了很久的一个系列，就推理游戏分类而言，我给8.5/10 
（PS:坐等汉化啊。虽然英文也完全没问题，但就莫名怀念当初玩的简中2333）

[I] This key was obtained from the publisher for Review Purposes. That won't affect the criticism in the end, but you should know that because of FTC guidelines, as well as the whole morals thing you know? [/i]

[b]Video Review: [/b] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WexUi8csBho
 
[b] Target Audience: [/b] [I]  Anyone who wants a mystery or an interesting story. Hell, for everyone.  [/i]

[u] Summary: [/u]
The Danganronpa series is the Phoenix Wright series on steroids. And it's one of the best experiences that I've had in the past 10 years. Danganronpa 2 received the highest score of games I've formally reviewed on the Youtube channel: and that's for good reason: it's fantastic from all sides of the spectrum. A good murder mystery needs to have a couple of basic elements to be successful, and Danganronpa 2 knocks each of them out of the park. An interesting set of characters with great backstories that make you connect with them almost immediately: which makes the pain of possibly losing/being betrayed by them that much better. The game does misdirection better then any other murder mystery out there, in particular with those who played the first game. This game knows how to get into your head, and knows how to play off what you may be thinking to twist it around on you. The game hooks you and doesn't let you go, and any minor problems I had with the game were knocked out by its sheer strengths of writing and drama. 

If you're looking for traditional gameplay, Danganronpa isn't that, but it's able to keep you interested with drama. If you haven't played the first, I'd recommend playing that first. It's great. Then play Danganronpa 2. Not only would you be glad that you did, but you'll remember the experience for a long, long time.

[u] Lists: [/u]
[b]Positives:[/b]
[list]
[*] Intrigue, Intrigue, Intrigue. This is a murder mystery, it lives off the mystery and shines throughout. You'll want to complete this all in one go, just because you'll be hooked. But you can't because....
[*] A fantastic set of characters that you'll connect to. There's a good variety here, and you'll want to complete each of their arcs to get a true understanding of their complex nature. 
[*] Writing is great. Messing with your head and expectations is what the game does best, and it does it in an interesting and compelling way.
[*] Misdirection. If you think you know what to expect....you're probably in for some surprises.
[*] Length. 24-30 hour campaign that doesn't slow down. And that's only for the main story. There's a bang for buck here, even if it's a Visual Novel.
[*] Does a great job of continuing from the first game and connecting the universe to it. It also understands how to do a sequel in the murder mystery genre.
[*] Little refinements on existing mini games was appreciated, helped to add a little more challenge.
[*] Difficulty settings were appropriate for the different levels so that wider audience could be reached. 
[*] Like the end-game content so that you can go back and complete all the character paths. 
[*] Have I mentioned the writing is amazing?
[*] Fantastic set of music to complement the action, but in particular, music that keeps the same base in several cases, but alters it for the trial/action in question. Very good job of complementing the emotion of the game.
[/list]

[b]Negatives:[/b]
[list]
[*] A problem with Alt tabbing, where changing context leaves you unable to get back into the game. Annoying.
[*] Some wrong control descriptions at one point. 
[*] Um......There's not much else that's wrong with it. All the other “problems” get fixed along the way in terms of plot, so you got to be in it for the long haul.
[*] That Danganronpa 3 won't be out in America in 2016. Because I'm a crack addict, and I need my fix.
[/list]

39228165.review:
As an aside, I want to note that DR2 is the first game that had a waifu I cared so much for and that says alot for me since I'm pretty indifferent about waifus until this game.

In regards to the game itself, at face value, it overall plays like a visual novel, but with a few twists. One such minor twist is being able to navigate through the environments freely at your leisure or during story-critical moments so it offers an extra dimension most other visual novels don't offer.

However, the meat of this game comes from its story and the cases that derive from it. If there is another series I had to compare this game to, it'd probably be Phoenix Wright due to the similar style of gameplay offered. You read statements and you point out contradictions with "Truth Bullets" given to you at the start of each argument where you take aim and take apart any person's statement during the argument. Sometimes, instead of refuting arguments, you can even agree with them which further increases the complexity of arguments and is a nice addition from the simplistic "find the contradiction" of the first game (which I ended up playing on an emulator). There are minigames that further supplement these trials, but they range from being very good such as Rebuttal Showdown and Logic Dive to gimmicky like Hangman's Gambit or Panic Talk Action (both of which were featured in the first game, but as different variations of them).

The character cast is amazing, which of course, is a matter of preference, but I never found myself truly hating the characters, even the annoying ones because the game offers a lot of characterization to them that creates a unique charm for each one of them. You go from having trouble trying to memorize 16 different names and faces to knowing each character and personality by heart as you progress through the game (due to the fact that the number of survivors will dwindle as is the nature of the game, but this is merely conjecture). Of note, the second core feature of the main game are the Free Time Events that allow you to strengthen your bonds with any character of your choosing by giving them presents that appeal to them. 

Of course, one must play the first game in order to play this to make any logical sense of the story, it's kind of a must. However, the huge step in quality as a game improves immensely over the first game both in its scope and in its narrative that it simply can't be ignored if you have a piqued interest for this series. 

As a final note, I will never see Space Invaders, Pac-Man, and especially Tetris the same way again.

39227638.review:
Ci sono dei riferimenti a Jojo. Quanti ho convinto a comprare il gioco dopo questa frase?

Iniziamo con un avviso: Danganronpa 2 è una netta evoluzione del primo capitolo, sia in positivo che in negativo. Se non avete gradito il design dei personaggi e la loro caratterizzazione, i twist narrativi o le fasi puzzle, state lontani da DR2. 
La struttura generale di questo sequel è pressochè identica al predecessore: un gruppo di 16 studenti si trova bloccato a loro malgrado su un isola tropicale con un orso bicolore a dargli sempre nuovi motivi per uccidersi a vicenda. Avvenuto il fattaccio si investiga sull'omicidio e si fa un processo per stabilire il colpevole. Il tutto sorretto da un cast, ancora una volta, estremamente curato nella caratterizzazione, una grande cura e qualità dei dialoghi ed un trama contorta e ricca di colpi di scena.
Grande pregio di DR2 è quello di avere un gruppo di protagonisti non solo migliore rispetto al primo, ma in generale uno dei più intriganti e fuori di testa del genere. Potrete amarli o odiarli fin dai primi momenti, ma ognuno avrà comunque qualche caratteristica o visione del mondo che vi rimarrà impressa (in particolare uno è indubbio che difficilmente vi sarà possibile dimenticarlo). Ovviamente per comprendere al 100% il background dei vostri beniamini dovrete fare amicizia con loro nello stesso modo del primo capitolo: scegliere di passare del tempo con loro e fargli dei doni a loro graditi così che si aprano di più verso di voi. Una volta completato il "social link" verrete ricompensati con vari tipi di skill utili nelle fasi puzzle. Sebbene più permissivo rispetto al passato, questo sistema costringe sempre ad una attenta scelta dei propri preferiti, visto che la loro improvvisa morte interromperebbe la progressione del social link e quindi risulterebbe in una grossa perdita di tempo per il giocatore. Anche questa disperazione tuttavia fa parte del gioco, dico bene? upupupupup
Il setting si sposa benissimo con lo stile psycho pop della serie e non diminuisce affatto il senso di angoscia che si provava girando per i corridoi della scuola del primo capitolo, anzi, per certi versi è persino aumentato in alcuni frangenti della storia.
Vera nota dolente sono i problemi di alcuni minigiochi che, come al solito, più si prosegue nella storia e più essi si complicano, oltre ovviamente ad avere una difficoltà base che stabilite all'inizio dell'avventura. L'hangsman gambit soffre particolarmente di ciò, arrivando ad avere blocchi di lettere che esplodono letteralmente ai bordi dello schermo perciò impossibili da intercettare. Inoltre negli ultimi due capitoli dell'avventura lo schermo viene interamente invaso da lettere rendendo improbabile perdere meno di un quarto di vita. 
Il confronto finale col colpevole (Panic talk action) ha un problema con l'hitbox delle note, cosa grave considerando che è sostanzialmente un rhythm game. Ciò non è serio a tal punto da compromettere il completamento del minigioco ed inoltre è facilmente compensabile usando il focus gauge che permette di non sbagliare mai una nota, tuttavia rimane poco funzionale e fondamentalmente meno coinvolgente.
Il rebuttal showdown e il logic dive sono probabilmente i più riusciti, con il primo che è una sfida tra due personaggi in cui si usano le prove per letteralmente tagliare le frasi avversarie e il secondo che rappresenta invece un ragionamento del protagonista vissuto come una corsa ad ostacoli.
Rimane comunque da far notare come i misteri dietro gli omicidi e i processi siano nettamente più divertenti da indagare e risolvere di proprio conto. Ovviamente va messo in conto quanto questo voglia significare casi ancora più assurdi, con picchi di improbabilità che coloro che non sono disposti a sospendere momentaneamente la loro incredulità faticheranno ad accettare. Francamente ritengo che questo sia parte del fascino della serie e trovo che sia anche un compromesso facilmente accettabile vista la trama così ben scritta e il fenomenale cast.
Ancora una volta le musiche sono azzeccate e ricche di personalità. Tra remix dal primo capitolo e nuove tracce è molto facile lasciarsi rapire dalla soundtrack in mezzo a tonalità tropicali e assoli di chitarra.
La longevità rimane molto alta: avventura completabile in circa 36 ore alla fine della quale si sbloccheranno un paio di modalità bonus. 
In sintesi: vi è piaciuto Trigger happy havoc? Amerete questo allo stesso modo se non di più. Non avete apprezzato il primo capitolo? Lasciate perdere, vuol dire che non è il genere per voi.

39156775.review:
Oh yeah, good old Danganronpa. How much have I missed hanging around a bunch of murderous wunderkinder, solving crimes and giving random gifts to people I've barely even talked to in exchange for extremelly personal info and creepy backstories. No, but honestly, when this game first came out it felt like reconnecting with a beloved crazy, morbid emo cousin. Awesome in one word.
Not only the title doesn't bring shame do it's successor's name, it's actually superior to it in many ways, not just the obvious ones like visuals (technology evolves afterall). Despite not being objectively vigger (at least not in a major way), switching the setting to a bunch of islands instead of a building (albeit huge one) reduced this claustrophobic, uncomfortable, distracting and unnecessary to the game's core aesthetic feeling I've been having to the minimum necessary to still enjoy the game's lore. If you thought first Danganronpa was a huge plottwists clusterfudge, fasten your seatbelts, cause this one's gonna be a wild ride till the very end. I'm not gonna spoil anything, of course.
The executions are more imaginative and personal than Trigger Happy Havoc's ones, at least most of them. The characters seem more extreme, but also better thought out, more fleshed out and detailed. Despite their unrealistic weirdness they actually seem more relatable, as their emotions are more conflicted and complicated, which gives them additional depth. Not to mention an absolutely badass protagonist trio. Look, I love Naegi, Byakuya and Kirigiri almost as much as I love my cat, but I really think Hajime, while still being a good person, is way more relatable than extremely kind, preacher-like Naegi. His flaws, inner struggles and growing insecurities made him the good old everyman we've all learnt to enjoy as a protagonist. Chiaki's accessibility (while still keeping the 'antisocial detective' persona), an amount of naiivness and kindness are what make her a bit more likeable than aloof, lvl over 9000 mystyrious Kirigiri. And don't even get me started on how she acted in chapter 5. Don't even get me started like this.
I also think that oh so controversial™ Komaeda makes a better foil/ally to the protagonist. He isn't a cold asshole just for the sake of success and survival (altough it also isn't the case with Togami; that's a huge mental shortcut, the dude has more or less tragic things behind him that shaped him to be so cruel, flatted-out and goal-oriented). This guy is, contrary to the popular belief, as honest as reasonably possivle, emotes quite a lot, actually desires to form bonds with others. His antagonistic behaviours are fuelled by past trauma, self-hatred, disease and ideals. He truly believes in everything he does and says. Aren't those things we, most likely non-elite members of society, can easilly connect to?
Multiple gameplay improvements have also been made. The impossible Closing Argument, that always seemed a bit unfair and arbitrary, now was simplified. As a player I didn't feel like I'm being deprived of challenge-I finally felt like the challenge had fair terms and rules. The pictures you can use to complete the comic have been split into groups and you're notified of your mistakes immediately, instead of shaking in your boots and waiting till the time comes. Small, vague hints  are the biggest help and remove all questionability if you remember the story perfectly.
The (improved) Hangman's Gambit has also, as the name suggests, improved. Now it poses aan actual challenge both as a puzzle and a dexterity-requiring minigame, that is fun on its own. The leveling system and e-pet (frequently called 'the tamagochi thing') prevented me from just transporting me wherever I needed to be transported, but made me walk around the gameworld and actually discover interesting objects and bonus events. Also, an e-pet is a fun distraction when murders and creepy backstories become a bit overwhelming.
To sum things up: the game kept it's prequels spirit and all that made me love the first Danganronpa, while expanding plot-wise and lore-wise and significantly improving gameplay, to make it challenging, but intuitional and enjoyable. I highly recommend it, even if you haven't played Trigger Happy Havoc, but enjoy a good mystery, smooth gameplay, rich plot and unforgettable characters. And some gore. May I warn you tough, the blood's still pink.

39051825.review:
Absolutamente fantástico. Aunque es obviamente reminiscente del primer juego, presenta un salto de calidad en prácticamente todos los aspectos. La historia es sublime, actúa como continuación de D1, pero mejora muchísimo el desarrollo y progreso. Los giros de guión, en especial, son fenomenales.

La jugabilidad es buena, pero no es por lo que el juego brilla. Las mecánicas de los juicios están muy bien pensadas, pero el resto del juego utiliza un sistema de point & click bastante clásico. No molesta, pero tampoco es nada especial.

Lo que verdaderamente hace brillar a este juego son dos cosas: los personajes y los elementos de misterio.

Los personajes. Qué decir de los personajes. SD2 nos presenta uno de los mejores elencos que he tenido el placer de ver en un videojuego. Todos son carismáticos y, aunque en un principio pueda parecer que no tienen profundidad, OS ASEGURO QUE SÍ LA TIENEN. Y MUCHA. En concreto, el trío protagonista (Hinata, Chiaki, Komaeda) es exageradamente interesante y tan profundo como entretenido. No os vais a hartar de conocerlos mejor y de ver como van evolucionando a la par que la historia. Respecto al resto de personajes, los otros 15 (13 alumnos, Monokuma, y Monomi), aunque no llegan al mismo nivel de perfección, no se quedan para nada atrás. Mención especial (aunque esto es algo muy subjetivo) para Sonia, Kuzuryuu y Gundam.

Por otra parte, el misterio es ridículamente bueno. El ambiente conseguido es espectacular. El misterio de la trama principal es increíble, pero es el de los asesinatos el que hace de este juego la absoluta maravilla que es. Cada muerte es inesperada, sorprendente y, sobre todo, intrigante. Conseguir ir despejando las incógnitas sobre los casos gracias a lo que hemos investigado previamente es MUY satisfactorio. Realmente te crees un detective real. Como en el apartado de personajes, mención especial para el quinto y, sobre todo, el cuarto juicio.

También me gustaría señalar la perfección con la que se manejan los temas tratados y la filosofía que envuelve al juego. A pesar de ser un juego de misterio, tiene tiempo para hablar de la importancia de la vida, de la amistad, del cariño, del odio, del amor, de la confianza, entre muchísimas otras cosas. Eso le suma, si cabe, todavía más puntos.

Si estáis dudando si comprarlo, yo os lo dejo claro: JUGADLO, DE VERDAD. Es una de las mejores experiencias que he tenido en este medio. Si le dais una oportunidad, no os arrepentireis.

39025822.review:
+Misterios +Aventuras +Asesinatos +Duración +Modos de juegos +Contenido +Desesperación...
Danganronpa 2: Goodbye Despair es la continuación de un juego que se impuso así mismo como un referente, un juego único en todo sentido por todos los modos de juego que involucra, convirtiéndose en una obra muy singular y querida.
Nos trasladamos a la Isla Jabberwock, donde nuevamente nos tocará involucrarnos con Monokuma y su loco circo de asesinatos y misterios, todo esto multiplicado por dos, ya que se nos incluye en la aventura a Monomi (Usami) lo cual aumenta nuestras dudas hacia quién ocupa cada rol o sea, ¿quién es el bueno?, ¿quién es el malo?, ¿quién es nuestro alido?, ¿Y quién nuestro enemigo?
Ya hablando más del juego en general es una gran aventura, no solo por el hecho de lo único que es en sí, sino también porque es una apuesta redoblada, repetir el mismo formato y que no se pierda la gracia de los misterios es algo muy difícil, pero en este caso Spike Chunsoft puede presumir que lo ha logrado, nos presentan multitud de enigmas que en ningún momento nos harán pensar... "hey, esto ya lo vi en Danganronpa, qué decepción...." por el contrario siempre nos dejarán pensando quién es el posible asesino o qué misterios se ocultan tras esta isla y tras Monokuma.
Jugabilidad correcta, muchos modos de juego que añaden horas al título e incluso una novela, ¿Qué más pedirle? Si he de marcar algo como negativo es el modo de juego de Usami, realmente creo que los desarrolladores pensaron que era más entretenido de lo que realmente fue.
¿Conclusiones? Un juego que vale totalmente la pena por su precio, por lo que nos ofrece, por ser un gran sucesor del juego original y por ofrecer la posibilidad de seguir observando y siguiendo la saga Danganronpa. Super Danganronpa, SUPER RECOMENDADO!

38998969.review:
Atención, reseña libre de spoilers.
¡¡¡Increíble!!! Juegazo. Siempre las segundas partes son malas, pero esta es la excepción.
Si a ti te gusto Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc, este juego te va a encantar, tiene casi el doble de contenido que el primer juego, incluyendo mecánicas y contenido adicional que complementa la historia de la saga.

Puntos positivos: 
•	Mecánicas añadidas, que le dan más emoción y variedad al juego.
•	Mayor rejugabilidad (extendiendo mínimo 10 horas adicionales tratando de sacar todos los logros comparado con el juego anterior) 
•	Resuelve partes de la historia planteada en Trigger Happy Havoc
•	Visualmente es mejor que el primero
•	Cuenta con más escenarios

Puntos negativos:
•	Otra vez el juego viene traducido solamente al inglés y se tienen las opciones de voces en japonés o inglés. Aunque, existe un parche en español hecho por los chicos de Transcene, el cual pueden descargar de la siguiente liga: https://transcene.net/Danganronpa-2.html   esta traducción es al castellano, así que a los latinos toca aprenderse algunas palabras para entender la trama al completo (vamos, que la traducción está muy bien hecha)

Conclusión.
Si eres fan de la saga y aun no has visto la serie de Danganronpa 3 (o ya la viste) es muy recomendable comprar y jugar este título, ya que es un nexo para entender la historia. En caso de no ser un fan de la saga, pero te interesaría introducirte en esta, te recomiendo jugar el primer juego o en todo caso ver el anime de Danganronpa: The Animation (porque hay ciertas mecánicas que llegan a chocar si juegas primero al 2 y después al 1). Y en ultima instancia si eres fan de los juegos de misterio, novela visual, de terror o de puzles, te recomiendo encarecidamente este juego.

Calificación: 9.8 (solo por lo de la traducción, Spike, porque nos abandonas :’c )

39409001.review:
Well, it's Danganronpa 2.

It's Danganronpa 1 but again. Not much more to say I guess? It's a game where you play a guy with an ahoge and solve murder mysteries. It's also a visual novel. That's the game, really.

Walking around is a little more awkward, in Danganronpa 1 you just walk around in a first person perspective and when you enter rooms you go into a 'room mode' and you can click on stuff. Danganronpa 2 does much the same thing but instead of a first person view, you get a mildly awkward looking sidescroller basically. Each of the islands you can visit in the game has basically a big circular road on it which you can loop around by running left or right forever. It's a little awkward and a little boring since you're just holding a button and waiting instead of, you know, actually going somewhere. The hallways of Hope's Peak from the first game was more engaging since you're always turning corners or looking for a staircase or whatever.

There's also a tamagotchi (yeah, you remember those stupid things?) that ties into the whole 'you can walk forever' thing. Because it has a step counter. However, if you walk too long without, uh, cleaning up after your tamagotchi it dies. So you have to micromanage the stupid thing, and the worst part is there's a bunch of different ones you can grow, so if you're going for 100% it's gonna take a lot of holding down left or right to get that particular achievement.

The gameplay's harder and different in a few ways to the first game. One of the minigames which in the first game is you clicking on letters to form words is now you clicking on bubbles that float across the screen. Bubbles that collide form together and 'stick' to the screen until popped or used, but if they're not the same letter then they will explode and damage you. It's a little sucky since it basically made an 'okay' minigame into something annoying. Also, the difficulty sort of scaled upwards in the first game - in this one it doesn't even care, one of the first 'words' you need to figure out is actually three words made up of like 13 letters.

There's more annoying stuff in this game too like, when you're in the middle of a class trial sometimes you'll be given new information or a new truth bullet or both or whatever, and this sometimes happens multiple times. It just kind of sucks.

Those are the bad things, I suppose. The rest of it's good, the characters this time are all debatably better than in the first - in that they all have wittier dialogue and basically all of the writing reads like anime comedy sketches. So if you like that, well, here you go.

Not much else to say, I guess? It's fun? It's good? Good story? Good characters? Good cases? Good gameplay? I mean I still like the first one better but this is definitely a worthy sequel.

39495582.review: Well i'd like to start this review by saying: play tthe first game (or watch the anime) before playing this. Honestly this game is fantastic the only problem i had was the game just took a little too long to actually start. I mean that in the sense of the introduction was a little longer then i would have liked. But once everything kicks in its great. Youre left with so many questions it makes you want to keep playing, because in teh beginnning nothing makes sense but not in an annoying way. Speaking of annoying, there's like only 1 annoyinh charecter that stays annoying but its not a big deal considering its part of their personality/character. Also the main character is great. He feels much more real the makoto and that is part of him as a person which is explored further in the game.The gameplay consists of you talking to people, walking around, discovering evidence/clues, and the class trials. The class trials are one of the highlights of this game. The atmosphere is unbelivable and the trial itself is kept interesting by having different parts for each one. Like for each trial there is the trial part then there are minigames that are fun for the most part. I say that because some arent always fun and can feel misplaced. Theres plenty of endgame content not gonna spoil anything but if you care enough you will be occupied for a while even after completing the game. Honestly if you like danganronpa and youve played the first game (or watched the first anime, dont bother with the other danganronpa anime) you will love this game. 9/10

39489655.review: Para ser sincero, você precisa ter um QI muito alto para entender Danganronpa 2. O humor é extremamente sutil e, sem uma compreensão sólida de física teórica, a maioria das piadas vai passar despercebida pelo telespectador médio. Há também a visão niilista de Monokuma, que está hábilmente tecida em sua caracterização - sua filosofia pessoal se baseia fortemente na literatura de Nododaya Volya, por exemplo. Os fãs entendem essas coisas; eles têm a capacidade intelectual para realmente apreciar a profundidade dessas piadas, para perceber que elas não são apenas engraçadas - elas dizem algo profundo sobre a VIDA. Como conseqüência, as pessoas que não gostam de Danganronpa são verdadeiros idiotas - é claro que eles não apreciariam, por exemplo, o humor no bordão existencial do Monokuma "UPUPUPUPU", que é uma referência enigmática para o épico Pais e Filhos do russo Turgenev. Estou sorrindo agora mesmo imaginando um desses coitados simplistas coçando a cabeça em confusão enquanto o gênio de Spike Chunsoft se desenrola na tela do seu PC. Que tolos... como eu tenho pena deles. E sim, a propósito, eu tenho uma tatuagem do Monokuma. E não, você não pode vê-la. É só para os olhos das damas. E mesmo elas, precisam demonstrar de antemão que possuem um QI com diferença absoluta de no máximo 5 pontos do meu (de preferência para baixo).

39567374.review: Danganronpa 2: Goodbye Despair manages to be even better than the already amazing first game. The trials are more complex, with less reliance on characters stating the obvious. The characters are even better than before, and I came to love almost all of them (Hiyoko was terrible though). Gameplay is still exceptional, with the exception of the "Improved" Hangman's Gambit minigame, which was terrible. Also, do not play this game if you haven't beaten the first and read a fan translation of Danganronpa Zero. Overall, an exceptional sequel that manages to be amazing despite my complaints.

39607382.review:
[h1]Esperanza vs Desesperación [/h1]

He visto todos los animes de Danganronpa y decidí comprarme el juego para saber que pasa en la "isla" de Jabberwock
algunas cosas ya las sabía y otras no. 

Los Juicios Escolares te prepara para la lucha por la esperanza con una banda sonora pegadiza y plot twists de lo más inesperados, más de una vez pensé tener al asesino contra la pared pero es tan sólo el principio de un largo juicio escolar.

Es una novela visual pero yo diria más que es un juego de detectives disfrazado de novela visual, en la que puedes acos- quedar con tus personajes favoritos y descubrir de su pasado que no te cuentan en la serie gracias al Tiempo Libre que te da para explorar comprar objetos etc.

Sí, desafortunadamente Danganronpa 2 esta en Inglés pero si miras por las guias de Steam o en Google encontrarás un parche totalmente en Español que recomendaria instalarlo desde el primer momento, ya que en Inglés te puedes liar o no entiendes muy bien lo que te intentan decir sobretodo en los juicios escolares.

Por todo lo demás un 9,5 

Nagito te QUIEROOO!!!
